results.title: Early sound recording equipment
results.brief_description: In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.

constellations_primary.name: Amateur hour
constellations_primary.description: Early sound equipment allowed filmmakers and amateurs alike the ability to experiment often with affordable 16mm film.

results.description:
Filmmakers had been trying to record sound on film since motion pictures were invented in the late 1800s but commercial systems for recording sound directly onto film took years of experimenting and innovating.

By 1929, synchronised sound, including Warner Brothers’ sound-on-disc Vitaphone system and RCA Photophone’s electrical sound-on-film system, were debuted. Once the technology was discovered, it only took five years for it to be available to amateur filmmakers.

In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.
description_for_label:
Filmmakers had been trying to record sound on film since motion pictures were invented in the late 1800s but commercial systems for recording sound directly onto film took years of experimenting and innovating.

By 1929, synchronised sound, including Warner Brothers’ sound-on-disc Vitaphone system and RCA Photophone’s electrical sound-on-film system, were debuted. Once the technology was discovered, it only took five years for it to be available to amateur filmmakers.

In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.

results.title: Dorothy Arzner and the boom mic
results.brief_description: Director Dorothy Arzner had a problem on the set of The Wild Party (1929). Her lead actress, silent-era ‘It’ girl Clara Bow, couldn’t perform energetically with the new microphones. To let her move freely, Arzner created the first boom mic.

constellations_primary.name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals
constellations_primary.description: The microphone was called the "terror of the studios" when sound films were introduced in the late 1920s, but after initial resistance Hollywood fully embraced the new technology.

results.description: Director Dorothy Arzner had a problem on the set of The Wild Party (1929). Her lead actress, silent-era ‘It’ girl Clara Bow, was having trouble transitioning to talkies. Bow was famous for her energetic, flapper-style performances, which she couldn’t do while being still for the microphone to record her dialogue. To let Clara move freely, Arzner rigged a microphone to a fishing rod and created the first ever boom mic. It wasn’t Arzner’s only achievement: The Wild Party was the first talkie directed by a woman, and she was the first female member of the Directors Guild of America – not to mention she made over 40 films during her illustrious career.
description_for_label: Director Dorothy Arzner had a problem on the set of The Wild Party (1929). Her lead actress, silent-era ‘It’ girl Clara Bow, was having trouble transitioning to talkies. Bow was famous for her energetic, flapper-style performances, which she couldn’t do while being still for the microphone to record her dialogue. To let Clara move freely, Arzner rigged a microphone to a fishing rod and created the first ever boom mic. It wasn’t Arzner’s only achievement: The Wild Party was the first talkie directed by a woman, and she was the first female member of the Directors Guild of America – not to mention she made over 40 films during her illustrious career.

results.title: Glass cinema slides
results.brief_description: These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, as well as the changing face of cinema when the Motion Picture Production Code was established.

constellations_primary.name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead
constellations_primary.description: The pre-code 1932 feature, A Bill of Divorcement, a glass cinema slide of which features in the glass cinema slide display, stars John Barrymore and Katharine Hepburn in her screen debut.

results.description: Hollywood studios spent a lot of money transitioning to talkies. To recoup the cost, they produced salacious films to attract big audiences. People certainly responded – including conservative groups, who pressured studios to protect family values. The Motion Picture Production Code was established in 1930 as a response but wasn’t enforced until 1934. These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, including A Bill of Divorcement (1932), which flouted the production code by exploring a marriage breakdown, as well as John Ford’s The World Moves On (1934), the first film to receive a Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors of America (now MPAA) certificate under the new Production Code.
description_for_label: Hollywood studios spent a lot of money transitioning to talkies. To recoup the cost, they produced salacious films to attract big audiences. People certainly responded – including conservative groups, who pressured studios to protect family values. The Motion Picture Production Code was established in 1930 as a response but wasn’t enforced until 1934. These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, including A Bill of Divorcement (1932), which flouted the production code by exploring a marriage breakdown, as well as John Ford’s The World Moves On (1934), the first film to receive a Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors of America (now MPAA) certificate under the new Production Code.

results.title: Music cue sheets
results.brief_description: In the silent era, studios began to create cue sheets that charted the major moments of a motion picture, along with what kind of audio accompaniment was recommended to match the action on screen.

constellations_primary.name: Right on cue
constellations_primary.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description: Although it was called the silent era, films of early cinema were never truly silent. From soaring scores performed by live orchestras to phonograph recordings, filmmakers were constantly searching for new ways to incorporate sound into the moving image. Studios began to create cue sheets that charted the major moments of a motion picture, along with what kind of audio accompaniment was recommended to match the action on screen. In Japan live musical accompaniment was complemented by benshi performers, who would provide live narration during a screening and helped silent films endure long after synchronised sound was introduced.
description_for_label: Although it was called the silent era, films of early cinema were never truly silent. From soaring scores performed by live orchestras to phonograph recordings, filmmakers were constantly searching for new ways to incorporate sound into the moving image. Studios began to create cue sheets that charted the major moments of a motion picture, along with what kind of audio accompaniment was recommended to match the action on screen. In Japan live musical accompaniment was complemented by benshi performers, who would provide live narration during a screening and helped silent films endure long after synchronised sound was introduced.
